items.title: Drywall Seams Still Showing? Feather Joint Compound With 120 Grit
items.description: If seams are still visible after drying, lightly sand the joint compound with 120 grit to knock down high spots and feather the edges before the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Joint Compound Feels Too Rough? Smooth Drywall Mud With 120 Grit
items.description: If dried drywall mud feels gritty or bumpy, sand it lightly with 120 grit to level the surface and remove high spots before applying the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Patch Not Blending Into the Wall? Prep It With 150 Grit
items.description: If a drywall patch edge stands out, sand the perimeter with 150 grit to feather the transition and level the surface before priming or painting. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Uneven Joint Lines After Mud? Level Drywall Seams With 120 Grit
items.description: If joint lines feel uneven after drying, sand the seam lightly with 120 grit to knock down ridges and level high spots before applying the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Mud Looks Lumpy? Smooth Joint Compound With 120 Grit
items.description: If dried compound has lumps or bumps, sand lightly with 120 grit to flatten high spots and smooth the surface before you skim or add another coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Seam Lines Visible Under Light? Feather Drywall Joints With 150 Grit
items.description: If seams show when light hits the wall, feather the joint edges with 150 grit to blend the transition and prep the surface for primer and paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Patch Edges Stand Out? Blend the Drywall Patch With 150 Grit
items.description: If a patch edge is still visible, sand the perimeter with 150 grit to feather the compound and blend it into the surrounding wall before primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Joint Compound Dried Too Hard? Dry Sand Mud With 120 Grit
items.description: If compound dried rock-hard, start with light pressure using 120 grit to cut high spots and even the surface, then wipe dust before recoating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Surface Feels Wavy? Flatten the Surface With 150 Grit
items.description: If the wall feels wavy to the touch, sand lightly with 150 grit to level minor highs and blend transitions before final paint prep. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Mud Lines Showing Through Paint? Prep Drywall With 150 Grit
items.description: If paint highlights mud lines, sand the area with 150 grit to feather edges and smooth the surface before primer or touch-up paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Repair Looks Obvious? Smooth the Area With 150 Grit
items.description: If a repair spot stands out, sand with 150 grit to feather the compound into the wall and smooth the surface before primer and paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Joint Compound Not Even? Level Mud Application With 120 Grit
items.description: If the mud dried uneven, sand lightly with 120 grit to knock down ridges and level high spots before you skim or apply another coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Patch Feels Raised? Level It With 120–150 Grit
items.description: If a patch sits higher than the wall, start with 120 grit to knock it down, then switch to 150 grit to feather the edges and blend the repair. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges of Mud Patch Too Sharp? Feather Drywall Edges With 150 Grit
items.description: If patch edges feel sharp or visible, feather them with 150 grit to blend the transition into the wall before final primer and paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Not Smooth Enough? Final Joint Prep With 150 Grit
items.description: If the surface still feels uneven, sand lightly with 150 grit to refine joints and feather edges before primer and paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Fresh Mud Shows Tool Marks? Remove Marks With 120 Grit
items.description: If dried mud shows knife lines, sand lightly with 120 grit to knock down tool marks and smooth the surface before your next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Seams Won’t Disappear? Blend Seams With 150 Grit
items.description: If seams keep showing, sand the joint edges with 150 grit to feather the transition and blend the compound into the wall before primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Joint Lines Still Visible? Final Drywall Prep With 150 Grit
items.description: If joint lines are still visible, sand lightly with 150 grit to feather edges and smooth the surface before primer and paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Mud Feels Grainy? Smooth Compound With 120 Grit
items.description: If joint compound feels grainy after drying, sand lightly with 120 grit to remove high spots and smooth the surface before recoating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Wall Not Ready for the Next Coat? Prep Drywall With 150 Grit
items.description: Before recoating, sand lightly with 150 grit to smooth small ridges and feather edges so the next coat lays down evenly. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Ridges Showing After the First Coat? Feather Drywall Mud With 180 Grit
items.description: If ridges show after your first coat, sand lightly with 180 grit to knock down high spots and feather the edges before applying the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Visible Between Coats? Blend Drywall Layers With 180 Grit
items.description: If edges show between coats, sand with 180 grit using light pressure to blend the transition and prep the surface before the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Second Coat Looks Uneven? Level Between Coats With 180 Grit
items.description: If the second coat dried uneven, sand lightly with 180 grit to level small highs and smooth the surface before you apply another coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Patch Not Blending Yet? Feather Sand the Patch With 180 Grit
items.description: If a patch still stands out, feather sand the edges with 180 grit to blend the repair into the wall before your next coat or primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Mud Buildup on Edges? Smooth Between Coats With 180 Grit
items.description: If mud built up along edges, sand lightly with 180 grit to smooth the ridge and feather it out before the next coat goes on. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Lines Showing After a Skim Coat? Lightly Feather Sand With 220 Grit
items.description: If lines show after a skim coat, use 220 grit with light pressure to feather the surface and smooth minor marks before the next coat or primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Raised Areas After Drying? Knock Down High Spots With 180 Grit
items.description: If you feel raised areas after the mud dries, sand lightly with 180 grit to knock down high spots and blend the surface before the next step. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Joint Lines Still Shadowing? Final Feather Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If seams still cast a shadow, use 220 grit with light pressure to feather the edges and smooth the surface before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Wall Feels Rough After Coat Two? Smooth the Surface With 180 Grit
items.description: If the wall feels rough after the second coat, sand lightly with 180 grit to smooth the surface and prep it for the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Patch Edges Catch the Light? Blend Drywall Edges With 220 Grit
items.description: If patch edges catch the light, sand with 220 grit using light pressure to blend the edge and smooth the transition before primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Between-Coat Texture Too Heavy? Refine Drywall Surface With 180 Grit
items.description: If texture feels too heavy between coats, sand lightly with 180 grit to refine high spots and smooth the surface before recoating. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Looks Flat but Feels Rough? Light Sand Between Coats With 220 Grit
items.description: If the surface looks flat but feels rough, do a light pass with 220 grit to smooth the feel and prep for the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Still Too Sharp? Controlled Feathering With 180–220 Grit
items.description: If edges still feel sharp, start with 180 grit to knock them down, then switch to 220 grit to feather smoothly and blend the transition. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Wall Not Smooth Before Paint? Final Between-Coat Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If the wall still isn’t smooth, make a light pass with 220 grit to refine the surface before the final coat, primer, or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Feathering Not Wide Enough? Expand the Feather Area With 180 Grit
items.description: If the blend zone is too narrow, sand outward with 180 grit using light pressure to widen the feather and smooth the transition into the wall. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: High Spots Showing on the Wall? Knock Down Drywall High Spots With 120 Grit
items.description: If you see high spots, sand lightly with 120 grit to knock them down and level the surface before you feather or recoat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Surface Looks Wavy? Flatten the Wall Surface With 150 Grit
items.description: If the wall looks wavy, sand lightly with 150 grit to level minor highs and blend transitions before final prep. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Tool Marks Left in Drywall Mud? Remove Tool Marks With 120 Grit
items.description: If knife lines are left in the mud, sand lightly with 120 grit to knock them down and smooth the surface before the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Scratches Visible on Drywall? Smooth Wall Scratches With 150 Grit
items.description: If scratches show on the wall, sand lightly with 150 grit to smooth the area and blend edges before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Patch Looks Bumpy? Level the Patch Area With 150 Grit
items.description: If a patch looks bumpy, sand lightly with 150 grit to level high spots and feather the edges before primer and paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Uneven Texture After a Repair? Blend Drywall Surface With 180 Grit
items.description: If a repaired area feels uneven, sand lightly with 180 grit to blend the texture into the surrounding wall before final prep. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Wall Surface Not Flat Enough? Correct Uneven Areas With 150 Grit
items.description: If the surface isn’t flat, sand lightly with 150 grit to reduce minor high areas and blend transitions before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Raised Lines Won’t Sand Out? Surface Correction With 120–150 Grit
items.description: If raised lines won’t sand out, start with 120 grit to knock them down, then switch to 150 grit to feather and smooth the area for finishing. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Feels Rough Under Hand? General Wall Smoothing With 150 Grit
items.description: If the wall feels rough, sand lightly with 150 grit to smooth the surface and blend minor imperfections before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Patch Area Still Noticeable? Blend the Repair Area With 180 Grit
items.description: If the repair is still noticeable, sand lightly with 180 grit to blend the patch into the surrounding wall before final prep. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Surface Imperfections Showing Through Paint? Final Wall Prep With 180 Grit
items.description: If paint reveals imperfections, sand lightly with 180 grit to smooth small highs and blend edges before primer or touch-up paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Repair Still Looks Messy? Surface Cleanup With 150–180 Grit
items.description: If a repair looks messy, start with 150 grit to smooth ridges, then switch to 180 grit to feather edges and refine the surface before primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Corners Look Uneven? Sand Inside Corners With 180 Grit
items.description: If inside corners look uneven, use 180 grit with light pressure to smooth ridges and blend the corner before the next coat. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Outside Corners Feel Too Sharp? Soften Drywall Edges With 150 Grit
items.description: If outside corners feel sharp, sand lightly with 150 grit to soften the edge and feather the compound for a smoother transition. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Corner Bead Showing Through? Blend the Corner Bead With 180 Grit
items.description: If the corner bead is telegraphing through, sand lightly with 180 grit to feather the compound and blend the edge before primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges of Patch Too Visible? Feather the Edge With 180 Grit
items.description: If a patch edge is still visible, feather sand with 180 grit to blend the repair into the surrounding wall before the next coat or primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Tight Spots Hard to Sand? Detail Drywall Sanding With 180 Grit
items.description: For tight spots, use a small folded piece of 180 grit to control pressure and smooth the area without over-sanding the surrounding surface. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Corners Catch the Light? Final Corner Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If corners catch the light, do a light pass with 220 grit to refine the surface and smooth the edge before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Look Overbuilt With Mud? Trim Drywall Edges With 150 Grit
items.description: If edges look overbuilt, sand lightly with 150 grit to trim down excess mud and feather the transition into the wall before the next step. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Corner Repairs Not Blending In? Blend Corner Repairs With 180 Grit
items.description: If corner repairs won’t blend, feather sand with 180 grit to smooth ridges and blend the repair into the surrounding corner before primer. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Drywall Edges Feel Rough? Smooth Edges With 150 Grit
items.description: If drywall edges feel rough, sand lightly with 150 grit to smooth the edge and feather the compound for a cleaner transition. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Detail Repairs Stand Out? Small-Area Blending With 180 Grit
items.description: If small repairs stand out, sand lightly with 180 grit to blend the patch into the wall without over-sanding the surrounding surface. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Corners Not Smooth Enough? Fine Corner Sanding With 220 Grit
items.description: If corners still aren’t smooth, use 220 grit with light pressure to refine the surface and remove minor marks before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Edges Still Too Harsh? Controlled Edge Sanding With 180–220 Grit
items.description: If edges still look harsh, start with 180 grit to soften them, then switch to 220 grit to refine and smooth the transition for finishing. Sandpaper eQualle

items.title: Final Touch Needed on Corners? Final Detail Prep With 220 Grit
items.description: If corners need a final touch, make a light pass with 220 grit to refine the surface and smooth minor marks before primer or paint. Sandpaper eQualle
